official-title.#text:
To establish a North and Central American and Caribbean border security cooperation initiative,
			 enhance the security of Mexico’s southern border, improve United States
			 short term detention standards, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committees on

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Central American and USA Initiatives Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Central American and USA Initiatives Act

header.#text: North and Central American border security cooperation initiative

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and other
			 appropriate United States officials, shall work with the appropriate
			 officials of the Government of Canada and the Government of Mexico, in
			 conjunction with representatives from the governments of Central American
			 countries, to establish a program to—

text.#text: The

assess the specific needs of Central American countries to maintain the security of the
			 international borders of such countries;

determine the support needed by such countries from the United States, Canada, and Mexico, to meet
			 such needs; and

assess the current structure for handling displaced minors and other vulnerable individuals in
			 Central American countries and recommendations to improve such structure.

Any actions taken pursuant to this subsection by the individuals referred to in paragraph (1) shall
			 be taken in accordance with the goals of advancing human rights and
			 economic opportunities, as well as programming and support for the rule of
			 law, good governance, and civil society.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to the Committee on

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives
Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a report on the assessments and
			 determination carried out in accordance with subsection (a).

Committee
			 on Foreign Relations of the Senate

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall work with
			 appropriate officials of the governments of the countries of the Caribbean
			 to establish a program to assess the specific needs of such countries to
			 address the unique challenges of maritime border security.

text.#text: The

text.#text: The

header.#text: Enhancing the security of Mexico’s southern border

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall work with
			 appropriate officials of the Government of Mexico to establish a program
			 to assess the specific needs of Mexico to help secure Mexico’s southern
			 border from undocumented aliens, drugs, weapons, and other contraband.
			 Such plan shall include—

text.#text: The

a comprehensive plan for the deployment and use of technology along the southern border of Mexico,
			 which at a minimum shall contain—
an assessment of current technology capabilities along the southern border of Mexico;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to help improve such capabilities; and

text.#text:
a description of the research and development capabilities of the Government of Mexico, and
			 collaboration between the Science and Technology Directorate of the

a description of Mexico’s technology needs to address southern border crossing transportation
			 screening, including vehicle, pedestrian and rail screening; and

a comprehensive plan for the repatriation of migrants to their home countries, which at a minimum
			 shall contain—

a description of the training, personnel and equipment needed to implement such a repatriation
			 program; and

an assessment of current and future land and rail ports of entry infrastructure that will be needed
			 to maintain legitimate border activity along the southern border of
			 Mexico.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall submit to the Committee on

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives
Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a report on the assessment of needs
			 carried out in accordance with subsection (a).

Committee
			 on Foreign Relations of the Senate

text.#text: The

header.#text: Improving United States short term detention standards

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall ensure that adequate facilities and sustaining needs,
			 such as access to food and water, medical care and sanitary facilities,
			 are provided to an individual apprehended and detained by a
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border
			 Protection

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
agent between ports of entry upon or as soon as practicable following the
			 time of such apprehension or during subsequent short term detention.

text.#text: The

header.#text:
Proper access to adequate facilities and personal needs upon or as soon as practicable following
			 apprehension and during short term detention at Border Patrol processing
			 centers
Access to information on detainee rights at Border Patrol processing centers

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall ensure that an individual unlawfully present in the
			 United States who is apprehended by a
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border
			 Protection

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
agent is promptly
			 provided with information concerning such individual’s rights, including
			 the right to contact a representative of such individual’s government for
			 purposes of United States treaty obligations.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
agent, and shall be posted in the detention
			 holding cell in which such individual is being held. The information shall
			 be provided in a language understandable to such individual.

text.#text:
The information referred to in paragraph (1) may be provided either verbally or in writing by the

Repatriations shall be limited to daylight hours and avoid locations that are determined to have
			 high indices of crime and violence.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
processing center for 72 hours or less, before
			 repatriation of such individual to such individual’s country of
